bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Florence M. Read, September 17, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] responds to a report by Lucian C. Smith that Read has sent him and states that the case described within is not likely to be yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Florence M. Read, September 17, 1923
div1.opener:
/LC
September 17, 1923.
Miss Florence M. Read,
Assistant Secretary,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Miss Read:
div1.p:
Referring to your letter of Sept. 14th., enclosing report of
Dr. Lucian Smith, I would say that whatever the case he reports may
be, it quite certainly is not yellow fever. Bright (unchanged) blood
is not vomited in yellow fever except when so large an amount is
poured out in the stomach that the gastric juice is unable to affectdarken it.
In such cases (and they are rare enough) the patient is extremely
jaundiced with spots of echymosis and dripping gums--dying in a few
hours.

closer.seg:
P.S. It could, however, have been a case
of y.f. with some other cause of profuse
gastric hemorrhage - i.e. gastric ulcer etc but
the case does not show the “ear marks” of
y.f. C.
